manuscript.title: Muraqqaʿ / مرقع
manuscript.calligrapher_note: No calligrapher ketebe (colophon inscription) or date is recorded in the album. The YEK catalogue entry explicitly states: 'bir hattatin ketebe kaydı ve tarih bulunmamaktadır' (neither a calligrapher's ketebe inscription nor a date is present). The album contains 21 letter-exercise pieces (harf meşkleri) in sülüs and nesih scripts, indicating a practice context rather than a finished presentation album. The absence of a ketebe is consistent with the meşk genre: practice albums were typically not formally signed.
manuscript.date_note: No date is inscribed in the album. The hatip ebru front cover and the red leather binding with crimson spine are consistent with a broad Ottoman Istanbul production range of approximately the 17th–18th century CE. The practice-album (meşk) format with sülüs-nesih letter exercises extends across this period without a distinctive terminus. Date null pending archival research or physical examination.
manuscript.format: Muraqqaʿ / مرقع — meşk murakkası (calligraphy practice album) with hatip ebru covers and cetvelli vassale interior
manuscript.format_note: A bound Ottoman calligraphic practice album (meşk muraqqaʿı) containing 21 letter-exercise pieces (harf meşkleri) in sülüs and nesih scripts across 21+I yaprak (leaves). The album's distinguishing decorative feature is its exceptional hatip ebru (floral marbled paper) front cover — a spectacular multi-petal flower composition in pink and orange/amber on dark brown stems against a grey-green battal ebru ground. The back cover is also marbled but with a distinctly different, more abstract leaf-and-petal composition, forming an unusual mismatched cover pair that may indicate replacement or repair of one cover. The interior pages use a consistent cetvelli framing system (2–3 line gold/olive + dark ink cedvel) with vassale window-mounting throughout, and small gold roundels and floral corner-pieces at panel junctions. Margins are plain cream/nohudi throughout — the triage-stage claim of colored mulevven margins was not confirmed at IIIF native resolution.
manuscript.script: Arap harfli — Sülüs (ثلث), Nesih (نسخ) — per YEK catalogue: 'Arap harfli — Sülüs, Nesih'

writing_area_mm.note: Writing area dimensions not recorded in YEK catalogue. Three-column layout of individual kıtʿa panels observed across all interior openings.

dimensions_mm.note: Outer dimensions 220×170 mm; 3 satır (lines per column panel) per YEK catalogue.

manuscript.folio_count_note: 21+I yaprak (21 leaves plus one additional leaf/guard) per YEK catalogue. 15 pages imaged via IIIF (pp. 001–015).
manuscript.yek_id_correction_note: YEK ID CORRECTED. Triage batch 2 recorded YEK ID 705363, which maps to TIEM 02213 (Muhur Mecmuası). Correct YEK ID is 705372, confirmed via murakka_album_pages_2_3.json search results and portal detail page (Koleksiyon no. 02426). All citations and URLs in this record use the corrected ID.
manuscript.notes: This album is the 4th confirmed hatip ebru specimen in the project corpus, joining tiem_02490 (matched hatip pair), damad_ibrahim_pasa_00027-001 (vikaye yaprağı hatip ebru), and tiem_02462 (hatip cover). The mismatched cover pair — a classic hatip ebru front with a different abstract-leaf marbled back — is a significant codicological observation: it may indicate (a) original production using two different ebru sheets from the same batch by convention, (b) later replacement of one cover following damage, or (c) deliberate aesthetic contrast. Physical examination of the binding structure (board attachment, paper lamination layers) would be required to distinguish repair from original design. The meşk (practice) nature of this album's calligraphic content distinguishes it from the presentation albums (tiem_02490, hamidiye_00010) and the master's album (tiem_02499): meşk albums were working objects, not gifts or status displays, which makes the hatip ebru cover relatively elaborate for the genre. YEK cataloguer: Nalan Kutsal.

paper_decoration.summary: TIEM 02426 presents two distinct decorative elements. (1) Marbled covers: the front cover (p001) bears a spectacular hatip ebru (imam's marbled paper) with fully developed multi-petaled flower clusters — pink and orange/amber blooms on slender dark brown stems — set against a grey-green battal ebru ground. The hatip flowers are clearly formed with 3–5 rounded petals per cluster, classic silhouetted floral forms executed in the hatip technique. The back cover (p015) is also marbled but exhibits a different pattern: elongated, acanthus-like leaf forms with feathered edges in grey-green, salmon/peach, and dark tones — consistent either with a variant hatip ebru in a more abstract register, or with a different ebru subtype (gel-git or free-form battal). This mismatched cover pair is the most significant codicological finding in this record. (2) Cetvelli framing system: all 11 interior calligraphy pages (pp. 002–012) display a consistent 2–3 line cetvelli border (gold/olive outer line + dark ink inner lines), enclosing vassale-mounted calligraphy panels in a three-column layout. Small gold gül (rosette) roundels and floral corner-pieces appear at the column and panel junctions throughout. The interior margins are plain cream/nohudi — no zerefşân, no mulevven coloring, no zerendud — confirming a single-decoration-zone program: all decoration is concentrated in the covers. The inside back cover doublure (p014) shows a pink/salmon paper lining, which is a colored binding component rather than decorated text paper.
paper_decoration.distribution_notes: Hatip ebru: front cover exterior only (p001). Marbled (abstract variant): back cover exterior only (p015). Cetvelli framing: all interior calligraphy pages (pp. 002–012). Pink doublure: inside back cover (p014) — binding component, not counted as decorated paper in classification. Plain endpapers/flyleaf: p002 (inside front cover) is plain cream. p013 (back flyleaf) is plain cream. Covers themselves (pp. 001, 015) are the only sites of decorated paper in this album.

technique_terms.ottoman: hatip ebru (çiçekli ebru / imamın ebrusu); battal ebru (zemin); ebrî / ebrulu kağıt; cetvelli; altın cetvel; vassale; gül (köşe süsü); meşk muraqqaʿı
technique_terms.arabic: waraq markhūm (ورق مرقوم) / waraq muzakhraf (ورق مزخرف) — decorated paper; jadwal (جدول) — frame ruling

catalogue_description.notes_field: Sülüs-nesih hatlarıyla harf meşklerinin yer aldığı, 21 yazıdan oluşan bu murakkada bir hattatin ketebe kaydı ve tarih bulunmamaktadır.
catalogue_description.notes_field_normalized: Sülüs-nesih hatlarıyla harf meşklerinin yer aldığı, 21 yazıdan oluşan bu murakkada bir hattatin ketebe kaydı ve tarih bulunmamaktadır.
catalogue_description.notes_field_translation: This album consisting of 21 calligraphic works containing letter exercises (harf meşkleri) in sülüs and nesih hands has neither a calligrapher's ketebe inscription nor a date.
catalogue_description.source: YEK portal, genel notlar field, record 705372 (CORRECTED from triage 705363), Türk ve İslam Eserleri Müzesi. Catalogued by Nalan Kutsal. Kağıt özellikleri and tezhip/minyatür fields are null in the YEK record. All paper decoration observations derive from visual examination of IIIF images at native resolution (15 pages, IIIF ID 0000000662585).

key_indicators: Hatip ebru (floral marbled paper) in the Ottoman tradition of the 17th–18th century is strongly associated with Istanbul production; the grey-green battal ground with multi-color pink and orange flower clusters corresponds to the standard hatip ebru palette of this period

The sülüs-nesih script combination in a meşk (practice) context is the standard repertoire of Ottoman Istanbul calligraphy training, particularly in the 17th–18th century period following the canonization of the Ottoman classical hand by Şeyh Hamdullah and Hâfız Osmân
Red leather binding with crimson textile spine is consistent with late Ottoman Istanbul binding conventions
The cetvelli vassale construction with gold roundels at panel junctions corresponds to standard Istanbul murakkaʿ production of the 17th–18th century
cross_tradition_caveats: No date, no ketebe, and no patron inscription are present; the broad 17th–18th century range cannot be narrowed without physical or archival evidence

The mismatched cover pair — two different ebru patterns on front and back — is unusual and may indicate a repair or replacement event, which would complicate provenance assessment: one cover may be original, the other later
Hatip ebru was produced at multiple Ottoman centers, not exclusively Istanbul; attribution to Istanbul is probable but not certain from visual evidence alone
The meşk (practice) genre spans a wide chronological and geographical range in Ottoman manuscript production; the genre itself does not constrain workshop attribution

paper.color: Covers: grey-green battal ebru ground + pink/orange flowers (front, p001); salmon/grey-green abstract leaf forms (back, p015). Interior calligraphy panels: cream/off-white burnished âharlı paper. Interior margins: plain cream/nohudi (natural paper tone). Inside back cover doublure (p014): pink/salmon lining paper.
paper.preparation: Calligraphy panels appear to be on standard Ottoman burnished âharlı (sized and burnished) paper, consistent with workshop calligraphy practice. The cetvelli frame is applied over the assembled vassale sheets. The covers are marbled papers adhered to the boards. The inside back cover is lined with a pink/salmon paper (doublure).
paper.weight: Indeterminate from IIIF images. Standard Ottoman murakkaʿ album weight expected.
paper.decoration: Front cover: hatip ebru (marbled). Back cover: marbled (abstract variant). Interior: cetvelli framing (gold/olive + dark ink ruling) with gold roundels at panel junctions. Vassale window-mounting throughout interior.
paper.paper_type: Oriental/Eastern paper for calligraphy panels; ebru (marbled paper) for covers; plain cream for endpapers and margins.

ruling.system: 2–3 line cetvelli (ruled border) on all interior calligraphy pages, with gold/olive-colored outer line and dark ink inner lines. Small gold gül (rosette) roundels at column junctions and floral corner-pieces at panel corners.
ruling.description: Every interior calligraphy opening (pp. 002–012) presents the same consistent cetvelli framing system: a 2–3 line border in gold/olive and dark ink enclosing the vassale-mounted calligraphy panels, which are arranged in three columns per page. Gold gül (rosette) roundels appear between the text columns and at the outer corners of the cetvelli border, providing decorative punctuation without elaborate illumination. The triangular fold-over corner marks of the vassale mounting are visible at the inner frame corners of each panel. The overall framing program is moderate in luxury level: consistent and carefully applied but not an elaborate multi-band framing system of the type seen in tiem_02499 or tiem_02490.

binding.cover_description: Front cover (p001): marbled paper (hatip ebru) with grey-green battal ground and multi-petaled pink + orange/amber flowers on dark brown stems, adhered to a board. Spine: red/crimson leather spine connecting front and back boards — no decorative elements on spine visible. Back cover (p015): marbled paper (abstract leaf/petal variant) in grey-green, salmon, and dark tones, adhered to a board. The two cover papers are visually mismatched — different ebru patterns, different color distributions. Library accession label visible on front cover (p001). Two labels visible on front cover: one small printed label (upper right) with TIEM reference. The binding is complete with a functional spine — no catastrophic structural damage visible.
binding.cover_type: Ebrulu cilt — marbled paper over boards with red leather spine
binding.notes: The mismatched front (hatip ebru) and back (abstract ebru) covers are the most significant codicological observation in this record. Possible interpretations: (1) Original production using two different ebru sheets, one hatip and one gel-git/abstract — this would be unusual but not impossible; most Ottoman murakkaʿ albums use either matched pairs or plain leather covers. (2) Replacement of one cover: the back cover may have been replaced (rebound) after damage to the original matched hatip cover; or conversely the front cover may have been a later upgrade from a plain or damaged original. Physical examination of board attachment, sewing structure, and paper-board lamination layers is needed to distinguish these scenarios. The front cover (p001) hatip ebru is in relatively good condition; the back cover (p015) shows more handling wear (corner creasing, tonal shifts). TIEM 02426 is the only confirmed mismatched-cover ebru album in the project corpus.

codicology.format: Muraqqaʿ / meşk murakkası — bound Ottoman calligraphic practice album (21+I yaprak)
codicology.condition_summary: Generally fair to good. Front cover hatip ebru (p001) is well-preserved: the floral motifs are vivid and clearly legible. Back cover marbled paper (p015) shows more surface wear, corner creasing, and tonal degradation. Interior calligraphy pages (pp. 002–012) are generally legible; some pages show foxing, partial soiling, and finger marks at page edges. The cetvelli framing is intact throughout. Vassale mounting is secure with no observed delamination at IIIF resolution. The inside back cover doublure (p014) shows the pink paper lining in fair condition. The back flyleaf (p013) is plain cream and in fair condition.

visual_confirmation.visual_evidence: All 15 IIIF pages examined at native resolution. Front cover (p001): hatip ebru unambiguously confirmed — pink and orange/amber multi-petaled flower clusters on dark brown stems against a grey-green battal ebru ground. Flowers are distributed across the full cover surface in an upward-growing compositional pattern, with each cluster showing 3–5 rounded petals. This is a textbook hatip ebru specimen: the silhouetted floral forms are the defining diagnostic of the technique. Back cover (p015): marbled paper confirmed — elongated acanthus-like leaf forms in salmon/peach, grey-green, and dark tones with feathered leaf-edges characteristic of ebru techniques; the pattern differs entirely from the front. Cetvelli framing confirmed throughout interior (pp. 002–012): consistent 2–3 line border in gold/olive + dark ink. Vassale mounting confirmed throughout: visible seam lines and triangular fold-marks at panel corners. Margins confirmed plain cream/nohudi. Colored mulevven not confirmed: margins on all interior pages (pp. 003–012) are natural cream throughout — no evidence of intentional coloring. Pink doublure confirmed at p014 as binding component only. Gold roundels at panel junctions confirmed across multiple interior pages.
limitations: Back cover marbling type (p015) cannot be definitively classified as hatip or gel-git/abstract at IIIF resolution; physical examination would allow inspection of the pattern structure in detail

The mismatched cover pair — front hatip ebru vs. back abstract ebru — raises a repair vs. original-design question that cannot be resolved from images alone; physical examination of board attachment and binding structure is required
No date or ketebe present; dating to 17th–18th century is a broad range based on stylistic indicators only

IIIF pages 002–012 confirm cetvelli and vassale, but the cetvelli gold ruling color (gold or olive-colored ink?) is ambiguous at download resolution — may warrant higher-magnification inspection for technique classification
p010 left page shows a faint blue-grey area at the top of one column that may be localized staining; unlikely to represent mulevven but not fully excluded

elements.motif: Hatip ebru — multi-petaled flowers on dark brown stems, grey-green battal ground
elements.description: The front cover is covered with an exceptional hatip ebru (imam's marbled paper) specimen. The ground is a grey-green battal ebru in a cloud-mottled, softly flowing pattern — the characteristic battal (stone/spot marbling) base that provides the background for hatip floral overlays. Against this ground, multiple flower clusters rise on slender dark brown stems: (1) PINK clusters: dense, rounded multi-petaled forms, each cluster 3–5 petals in deep rose-pink, distributed across the cover in at least 6–7 positions; (2) ORANGE/AMBER clusters: similar multi-petal rounded forms in a warm amber-orange tone, appearing alternately with the pink clusters — together giving a two-color floral palette on the same battal ground. The stems are dark brown/sepia, slender and curved, emerging from the lower part of the cover and branching upward. Each stem carries one or two flower clusters at its tip. The composition is upward-growing from multiple stem origins across the cover width, creating a dense botanical surface. The silhouetted floral forms — the defining diagnostic of the hatip ebru technique — are fully developed and unambiguous. A TIEM library accession label is affixed to the upper right area. Binding spine (right edge) is red/crimson leather. A scale ruler is visible along the right edge.

folio_analyses.notes: This is one of the clearest hatip ebru specimens in the project corpus. The combination of pink and orange/amber flowers on a grey-green battal ground is a classic Ottoman hatip ebru palette. The compositional density — 6–7 upward-growing stem clusters across the cover — indicates a high-quality specimen. This is the 4th confirmed hatip ebru in the corpus (after tiem_02490 matched pair, damad_ibrahim_pasa_00027-001 vikaye yaprağı, and tiem_02462 cover).

elements.motif: Cetvelli framing — 2–3 line border in gold/olive + dark ink
elements.description: Both pages of the opening show the standard cetvelli border system of this album: a 2–3 line ruled border frames the entire vassale-mounted calligraphy panel area. The outer line is in gold or olive-colored ink; the inner line(s) are in dark ink. The border creates a rectangular frame around the three calligraphy columns on each page. The interior margins between the frame and the book edges are plain cream/nohudi paper.

elements.motif: Gold gül roundels and floral corner-pieces at panel junctions
elements.description: Between and around the three calligraphy columns, small gold gül (rosette) roundels are visible at the column junctions. These appear as small circular medallion motifs in gold/olive coloring. Floral corner-pieces appear at the outer corners of the cetvelli border. The motifs are modest in scale and execution — standard murakkaʿ album embellishments.
elements.location: Panel junctions and outer corners, both pages

elements.motif: Vassale window-mounted calligraphy panels — sülüs and nesih letter exercises
elements.description: Each page carries three vertical calligraphy panels arranged in columns, window-mounted via the vassale technique. The calligraphy panels are clearly on a slightly whiter paper than the surrounding margin paper. Triangular fold-over marks are visible at panel corners. The calligraphy content consists of Arabic letter-form exercises (harf meşkleri) in sülüs (large, bold strokes with strong thick-thin contrast) and nesih (smaller, rounder, more regular forms) scripts. Individual Arabic letters and short syllable combinations are practiced in sequence. The three-column layout is consistent across all interior openings and reflects the standard meşk format for letter-by-letter practice.
elements.location: Three calligraphy columns per page, both pages

folio_analyses.notes: The margins are plain cream throughout. No zerefşân, no mulevven tinting, no halkar. The decoration is entirely structural (cetvelli framing + vassale mounting + gold roundels). This confirms the triage-stage finding that 'colored margins' was a false positive — the slight tonal difference visible at low resolution between the writing paper and margin paper is the standard vassale two-paper effect.

elements.motif: Cetvelli framing — consistent with pp. 002–012 system
elements.description: Both pages show the same cetvelli framing as p003: 2–3 line gold/olive + dark ink border enclosing the three-column vassale panel layout. The border is consistently applied. Triangular vassale fold-marks are clearly visible at panel corners on both pages — particularly legible on the left page, providing the clearest evidence of the window-mounting technique in the album.

elements.motif: Vassale corner marks — triangular fold evidence
elements.description: The triangular fold-over marks at the corners of the calligraphy panels are more prominent on this opening than on pp. 002–003, confirming the vassale window-mounting construction throughout. The tonal difference between writing paper (slightly whiter) and margin paper (slightly warmer cream) is visible but subtle — consistent with aged paper variation, not intentional mulevven coloring.

elements.motif: Gold gül roundels and floral corner ornaments
elements.description: Gold gül roundels at column junctions and outer corner floral ornaments are consistent with earlier openings. The gold-colored decorative elements are visible against the cream ground.
elements.location: Panel junctions and outer corners, both pages

folio_analyses.notes: This opening provides the clearest visual evidence for the vassale technique due to the prominence of the triangular corner fold-marks. The margins are conclusively plain cream/nohudi with no coloring.

elements.motif: Cetvelli framing — continuing system, mid-album state
elements.description: Both pages show the cetvelli framing system consistent with all interior openings. The border is intact and evenly applied. The mid-album pages (pp. 007–010) show slightly more handling wear than the opening pages, with some foxing visible at page edges. The three-column calligraphy layout continues.

elements.motif: Gold gül roundels — consistent with earlier openings
elements.description: Gold gül roundels at column junctions visible as per earlier pages. The overall decorative program is uniform across all interior openings with no variation or deterioration of the framing scheme mid-album.

elements.motif: Sülüs-nesih harf meşkleri — mid-album letter exercises
elements.description: The calligraphy content continues as letter-form exercises. Both the bold sülüs strokes and the smaller nesih forms are present across the three columns per page. Some ink bleed-through is visible on the left page, consistent with practice calligraphy. The meşk format shows working use — this is a functional practice album.
elements.location: Three calligraphy columns per page, both pages

folio_analyses.notes: Mid-album pages confirm the uniform decorative program. No change in paper type, color, or framing system across the interior. The album's decoration is entirely consistent from p002 to p012.

elements.motif: Abstract marbled paper — elongated leaf/petal forms in grey-green, salmon, and dark tones
elements.description: The back cover is covered with a marbled paper that differs entirely from the front cover hatip ebru (p001). This paper exhibits: (1) Large, elongated leaf/petal forms with feathered edges, in salmon/peach and grey-green tones, sweeping diagonally across the cover surface in flowing curves; (2) Dark brown/charcoal areas creating tonal contrast and shadow within the leaf forms; (3) An overall composition that is more abstract and flowing than the structured floral pattern of the front cover — no clear individual flower heads with petals are distinguishable; instead, the pattern suggests large acanthus-like leaves in motion. The color palette (salmon/peach, grey-green, dark) overlaps partially with the front cover but the pattern structure is entirely different. This may be classified as: (a) a gel-git (combed) ebru in which the combing has elongated battal spots into leaf-like forms; (b) a variant hatip ebru in a more abstract, less structured register; or (c) a free-form battal ebru that has been manipulated to create flowing directional forms. The classification remains uncertain without physical examination. Two library accession labels are affixed to the left edge. Spine (right edge): red/crimson leather.

folio_analyses.notes: The back cover is conclusively marbled but its subtype (gel-git vs. abstract hatip vs. free-form battal) cannot be determined with certainty from IIIF images. The critical observation is the mismatch with the front cover: two different ebru patterns on the same binding. This is the most significant codicological finding in this record. Physical examination of the binding structure would clarify whether the mismatch is original (two different sheets from same batch) or the result of later repair/rebinding.

terms_used.ottoman: hatip ebru / imam ebrusu / çiçekli ebru (حاطب ابرو)
terms_used.persian: kāġaẕ-i abrī-yi gul-dār (کاغذ ابری گل‌دار) — marbled paper with flowers
terms_used.english: Hatip ebru (lit. 'imam's marbling'): a specialized Ottoman marbling technique in which floral or botanical motifs — typically stylized flowers with rounded petals on stems — are created in the marbling trough by drawing paint into the battal base with a pin or stylus. The resulting silhouetted flowers are the defining diagnostic of the technique. Named after Hatip Mehmet Efendi (17th century), who is credited with perfecting the floral forms. The grey-green battal ground + pink/orange flower palette of TIEM 02426 is a classic Ottoman hatip ebru color scheme. This is the 4th confirmed hatip ebru specimen in the project corpus.

Battal ebru (lit. 'bold/plain marbling'): the base form of ebru in which drops of pigment are floated on the carrageenan size and spread into irregular cloud-like spots without further manipulation. Battal ebru serves as the ground (zemin) for hatip ebru, providing the mottled grey-green background against which the hatip flowers are created. In TIEM 02426, the grey-green battal ground is clearly visible between the flower stems.

A binding in which the front and back covers bear different decorative papers or patterns. In TIEM 02426, the front cover (p001) has a classic hatip ebru with structured pink+orange flowers on grey-green battal, while the back cover (p015) has a different, more abstract marbled pattern with elongated leaf/petal forms in salmon, grey-green, and dark tones. Such mismatches may indicate: original design with deliberately contrasting papers; repair or replacement of a damaged cover; or use of two sheets from different batches in a single production run. Physical examination is required to distinguish these scenarios.

Meşk muraqqaʿı: an Ottoman calligraphic practice album (as opposed to a presentation album or kıtʿa collection). Contains letter exercises (harf meşkleri) rather than finished calligraphic compositions. TIEM 02426 contains 21 such exercises in sülüs and nesih scripts. Meşk albums were working objects, used by students or masters to practice and demonstrate letterform sequences, and were typically not formally signed with a ketebe inscription.

terms_used.arabic: taḥrīr al-ḥurūf (تحرير الحروف) — letter writing practice
terms_used.english: Harf meşki: a calligraphic exercise focused on individual Arabic letter forms or short combinations, as opposed to complete texts or compositions. The 21 pieces in TIEM 02426 are described as harf meşkleri in the YEK catalogue, distinguishing this as a training album rather than a presentation piece.

Vassale: a mounting technique in which the calligraphy (or painting) panel is set into a window cut from a larger sheet of decorated or plain paper, with the panel edges folded over at the back. The resulting composition has the calligraphy panel as a 'floating' element surrounded by the margin paper. Diagnostic signs: slight tonal difference between panel paper and margin paper; seam lines at panel edges; triangular fold-over marks at corners. Confirmed throughout all interior pages (pp. 002–012) of TIEM 02426.

terms_used.persian: jadval (جدول) — frame ruling; jadval-keshī (جدول کشی) — rule-drawing
terms_used.english: Cetvel: ruling lines drawn to frame the calligraphy panel in Ottoman manuscripts and albums. In TIEM 02426, the cetvelli border consists of 2–3 lines: an outer line in gold or olive-colored ink and inner line(s) in dark ink, enclosing the full panel area on each page. The cetvelli system is the primary (and only) interior decorative element of this album beyond the vassale mounting.

Gül: a rosette or circular medallion motif used as a decorative punctuation element. In TIEM 02426, small gold gül roundels appear at the junctions between the three calligraphy columns and at the outer corners of the cetvelli border, providing modest decorative enrichment to the framing system without elaborate illumination.

terms_used.ottoman: renkli iç kapak / boyalı iç kapak
terms_used.english: The inside back cover (doublure, p014) of TIEM 02426 shows a pink/salmon-colored paper lining. This is a binding component — a colored paper used as the interior cover lining — rather than a decorated text page or margin. It is not classified as mulevven (colored paper decoration) in this record because it is a structural element of the binding, not a decorated writing surface.

Sülüs (thuluth): one of the six classical Arabic scripts, characterized by large, rounded letterforms with strong contrast between thick and thin strokes. One of the two scripts practiced in the letter exercises of this album.

Nesih (naskh): a small, rounded, clear Arabic script widely used for manuscript copying. One of the two scripts practiced in the letter exercises of this album. The sülüs-nesih pairing is the standard Ottoman calligraphy training curriculum.

bibliography.citation: Barutçugil, Hikmet. Ebru: Türk Kağıt Süsleme Sanatı / The Turkish Art of Marbling. Istanbul: Tibyan Yayıncılık, 2010.
bibliography.relevance: The most comprehensive Turkish monograph on ebru technique, directly relevant to the hatip ebru classification of the front cover and the ebru-type analysis of the back cover. Barutçugil documents the hatip ebru technique including the characteristic grey-green battal ground and floral palette, provides comparative images for the pink+orange flower color scheme, and discusses the relationship between battal, hatip, and gel-git subtypes. Essential for contextualizing the mismatched cover pair.
bibliography.access_notes: Turkish/English bilingual monograph; held at Turkish art libraries and specialist collections. Standard reference for ebru technique in the Ottoman tradition.

bibliography.citation: Blair, Sheila S. 'Color and Gold: The Decorated Papers Used in Manuscripts in Later Islamic Times.' Muqarnas 17 (2000): 24–36.
bibliography.relevance: Foundational taxonomic study of decorated papers in Islamic manuscripts, including marbled (abrī) papers. Blair's classification framework provides the basis for distinguishing battal ebru (stone marbling) from hatip ebru (floral marbling) and for situating both within the broader decorated paper taxonomy. Her documentation of marbled paper as a category distinct from gold-sprinkled and stenciled papers underpins the classification in this record.
bibliography.access_notes: Peer-reviewed article; available via JSTOR (Brill/Muqarnas Online). Open-access PDF at Academia.edu.

bibliography.citation: Roxburgh, David J. The Persian Album, 1400–1600: From Dispersal to Collection. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2005.
bibliography.relevance: Essential study of the murakkaat album format and its decorated paper programs across the Persianate-Ottoman tradition. Roxburgh provides the theoretical framework for understanding marbled paper as a deliberate compositional choice in album design, the relationship between cover decoration and interior decoration programs, and the distinction between meşk albums and presentation albums. Relevant for situating TIEM 02426 within the broader murakkaʿ genre.
bibliography.access_notes: Monograph; widely held at research libraries.

bibliography.citation: Derman, M. Uğur. Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998.
bibliography.relevance: Primary English-language exhibition catalogue on Ottoman calligraphy, covering the sülüs-nesih curriculum, meşk practice albums, and the calligraphic training tradition in Istanbul. Relevant for understanding the meşk muraqqaʿ format, the sülüs-nesih pairing as the standard Ottoman training repertoire, and the absence of a ketebe in practice albums as opposed to presentation pieces.
bibliography.access_notes: Exhibition catalogue (Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998); widely held.

bibliography.citation: Çağman, Filiz, and Zeren Tanındı. The Topkapı Saray Museum: The Albums and Illustrated Manuscripts. Translated and edited by J. M. Rogers. Boston: Little, Brown, 1986.
bibliography.relevance: Standard reference for Ottoman calligraphic albums and their decorated paper programs in the Topkapı collections. Provides comparanda for murakkaʿ albums with marbled covers and cetvelli interior framing systems from the 17th–18th century. Relevant for situating TIEM 02426's binding type and interior decorative program within the documented Istanbul album corpus.
bibliography.access_notes: Exhibition catalogue; widely held at Turkish and Islamic art research libraries.

bibliography.citation: Bloom, Jonathan M. Paper Before Print: The History and Impact of Paper in the Islamic World. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2001.
bibliography.relevance: Comprehensive history of paper production and use in the Islamic world, providing material-culture background for marbled paper production (ebru), the role of decorated covers in Ottoman book culture, and the general framework for understanding why a practice album would receive a hatip ebru cover.

bibliography.citation: Gacek, Adam. Arabic Manuscripts: A Vademecum for Readers. Leiden: Brill, 2009.
bibliography.relevance: Standard reference for Islamic manuscript codicological terminology, including script identification (sülüs, nesih), album formats (murakkaat), vassale mounting, and general physical description vocabulary. Relevant for the codicological description of TIEM 02426's structure and the meşk format.

bibliography.citation: Déroche, François. Islamic Codicology: An Introduction to the Study of Manuscripts in Arabic Script. Translated by Deke Dusinberre and David Radzinowicz. London: Al-Furqan Islamic Heritage Foundation, 2005.
bibliography.relevance: Foundational reference for Islamic manuscript codicology, covering paper types, binding forms, ruling systems, and the physical structure of albums. Provides the framework for classifying the vassale technique, cetvelli framing, and cover decoration. The binding analysis of TIEM 02426 draws on Déroche's terminology.

bibliography.citation: Scheper, Karin. The Technique of Islamic Bookbinding: Methods, Materials and Regional Varieties. Leiden: Brill, 2015.
bibliography.relevance: Systematic study of Islamic bookbinding techniques, relevant for physical analysis of the mismatched cover pair — the central codicological question in this record. Scheper's documentation of Ottoman binding construction, board attachment, and cover paper application is directly applicable to assessing whether the back cover of TIEM 02426 is a later replacement or original production.
bibliography.access_notes: Monograph; available at Islamic bookbinding and manuscript studies libraries.

bibliography.citation: Tanındı, Zeren. 'Bibliophile Aghas (Eunuchs) at Topkapı Saray.' Muqarnas 21 (2004): 333–43.
bibliography.relevance: Documents album-collecting and commissioning practices at the Ottoman court in the 17th century, providing context for the patronage environment within which meşk albums with decorated covers were produced. Relevant for understanding why a practice album (meşk muraqqaʿı) might receive an elaborate hatip ebru cover — particularly if it was associated with a collector or teaching environment in the court sphere.

suggested_collections.institution: Türk ve İslam Eserleri Müzesi (TIEM), Istanbul — broader murakkaʿ corpus
suggested_collections.reason: TIEM holds 93 confirmed murakkaʿ albums (all positive in visual triage, 2026-02-28). Systematic comparison with the other confirmed hatip ebru albums (tiem_02490 matched pair, tiem_02462 cover) and with albums in the cetvelli-only framing category is the most direct route to contextualizing TIEM 02426's decoration and assessing the mismatched cover question.

Holds the largest corpus of documented Ottoman calligraphic albums with hatip ebru papers, including albums linked to the court calligraphy training tradition (Şeyh Hamdullah, Hâfız Osmân circles). Physical comparison of hatip ebru cover pairs from Topkapı with TIEM 02426's mismatched pair would help establish whether the mismatch is an original production convention or a later intervention.

Major collection of Ottoman calligraphic albums with decorated covers, including hatip ebru specimens. Provides international comparanda for the cover decoration program and the meşk album format. CBL holds several albums with mismatched or non-standard cover pairings that may provide analogs for TIEM 02426's front-back discrepancy.

The primary active research project on decorated papers in Islamic manuscripts. The back cover marbling type (gel-git vs. abstract hatip vs. free-form battal) and the mismatched cover question fall within GlobalDecoPaper's research scope for ebru classification and provenance.

provenance.notes: Held at Türk ve İslam Eserleri Müzesi (TIEM), Istanbul, under shelfmark T 02426. TIEM is a Turkish state museum holding former imperial and private collections acquired during the early Republican period and subsequently. The manuscript entered the collection at an undetermined date prior to YEK registration. No waqf (endowment) information, donor name, or previous owner inscription is recorded in the YEK catalogue or visible in the IIIF images. YEK ID: 705372 (CORRECTED from triage value 705363, which corresponded to TIEM 02213 — Muhür Mecmuası). IIIF ID: 0000000662585. Catalogued by Nalan Kutsal (YEK portal).

analysis_metadata.image_source: YEK Portal IIIF images, TIEM Yazma Eser Koleksiyonu, YEK ID 705372, IIIF ID 0000000662585. All 15 IIIF pages (pp. 001–015) downloaded and examined. Primary visual confirmation data from catalog/searches/visual_tier2_tiem_02426.json. Direct IIIF examination at native resolution by metadata-generator for folio analysis entries (p001, p003, p005, p007, p015).
analysis_metadata.image_quality_notes: IIIF images are clear and support confident identification of the hatip ebru front cover and the mismatched abstract ebru back cover. The cetvelli framing and vassale mounting are legible across all interior pages. The interior margins are clearly cream/nohudi throughout — the absence of mulevven coloring is definitively established at native IIIF resolution. Gold ruling color (gold vs. olive-colored ink) cannot be determined with certainty at download resolution; higher-magnification examination would be required. The back cover marbling subtype (gel-git vs. abstract hatip) cannot be classified with full certainty from images; physical examination is recommended for this determination.
analysis_metadata.folios_not_examined: All 15 available IIIF pages examined. The album has 21+I yaprak per YEK catalogue; 15 IIIF pages are digitized. Pages beyond p015 (if any) may correspond to un-digitized leaves.
analysis_metadata.corpus_priority: Medium-high. The hatip ebru front cover is a high-quality specimen (4th in corpus) and the mismatched cover pair is unique in the corpus. The meşk genre context distinguishes this from the presentation albums that dominate the confirmed hatip specimens. Priority follow-up: (1) physical examination of binding structure to assess whether the cover mismatch is original or repair; (2) physical examination of back cover marbling to classify subtype (gel-git vs. abstract hatip vs. free-form battal); (3) comparison with other TIEM hatip ebru specimens (tiem_02490, tiem_02462) for palette and technique relationships.
